source.name: Printing: Reading Question 1
source.instructions:
What is wrong with the code snippet below?
```
cout << Hello world!;
```

answers.answer: Remove the `;` at the end of the code

source.guidance: Quotation marks are needed around your desired output in order for it to print.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT choose the correct cout command to write text to the console

source.name: Printing: Reading Question 2
source.instructions: Select **all** of the following commands that add a newline character?
source.guidance: Both choices #2 and #3 are correct and will produce the same output. `Hello` will be printed followed by a newline character.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT choose the correct commands that add a newline character

source.name: Printing: Reading Question 3
source.instructions: Fill in the blanks below about comments in C++.
source.text: In C++, the `//` symbol means a <<<single-line>>> comment, and the `/*` and `*/` symbols mean a <<<multi-line>>> comment.
source.guidance: In C++, the `//` symbol is used for a single-line comment. The comment begins at the `//` and goes on until the end of the line. The `/*` and `*/` symbols are used for multi-line comments. You must start with the `/*` and end with the `*/`. Everything between the start and end symbols will be considered the comment.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recall how to create single-line and multi-line comments by using // and /* */ respectively

text: In C++, the `//` symbol means a
comment, and the `/*` and `*/` symbols mean a

source.name: Print Statement
source.instructions: What does the `cout <<` statement do?

answers.answer: Sends your output to the printer
Sends your output to a file
Sends your output to the screen
Sends your output to the compiler

source.guidance: The `cout <<` command sends your output to your computer's default output which is the computer console or terminal.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recall what the cout command does

source.name: Printing with the Newline Character
source.instructions: Fill in the blanks with the missing commands that will print the text `Hi!` **with** a newline character. **DO NOT** include any leading or trailing **spaces** when printing `Hi!`.
source.guidance: The `"Hi!"` will print the text `Hi!` and the `endl;` will add a newline character. **Don't forget to include the `;` after `endl`.**
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT show how to add a newline character with the endl command

source.name: Variables
source.instructions: Select **all** of the properties of a variable below that **do not** change?
source.guidance: For each variable, the data type and name of the variable never change. The value can be re-assigned or changed as many times as you want!
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT name the properties of a variable

source.name: Integers
source.instructions: Which of the following values for `number` will produce the output `1000000` when printed using `cout << number << endl;`?
source.guidance:
Only choice #2 is correct. Choices #1 and #3 will result in an error message and choice #4 will output `262144`. 

The reason for `262144` being printed is due to the fact that **octal** numbers start with a `0`. Thus, the system converts `01000000` from an octal number to a decimal number which equals `262144`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT understand how to assign a value to a variable

source.name: Numbers: Int vs. Double
source.instructions: Fill in the following with the appropriate vocabulary to explain the difference between a double and an int.
source.text: A <<<double>>> is a <<<floating point number>>> meaning it has a <<<decimal>>>, where an <<<int>>> is a <<<whole number>>> meaning it does not have a decimal.
source.guidance:
A `double` is a floating point number or a rational number meaning it has a decimal or represents a fraction, where an `int` (short for integer) is a whole number meaning it does not have a decimal.

Both can be positive or negative!
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain the difference between an integer, double, and float

text: meaning it does not have a decimal.

source.name: Boolean
source.instructions: What is the general rule for boolean values in C++?

answers.answer: Boolean values are case sensitive and must be lowercase.
Boolean values are not case sensitive and can be either uppercase or lowercase.
Boolean values are case sensitive and must be uppercase.
Boolean values are case sensitive and must be all capitalized.

source.guidance: Boolean values in C++ are case sensitive and must be in all lowercase letters: `true` or `false`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT summarize the rules for assigning a value to a boolean variable

source.name: Strings
source.instructions: Select the correct line of code to declare and assign the `var` variable. Drag your selected answer to the highlighted yellow space below. Then click `Check It!`.
source.guidance: In C++, `string` must be in lowercase. The string must also be surrounded by double quotation marks `"`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT demonstrate their understanding of declaring and assigning a value to a string variable

source.name: Declaring Variables
source.instructions: Which of the following code snippets contains correct variable declarations?
source.guidance:
C++ does not allow different variables to have the same name - regardless of data type.

Additionally, C++ does not allow spaces in variable names - either use `camelCase` or `snake_case` to separate words.

Since C++ variables are case sensitive, `var` and `Var` are different variables.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT summarize the rules for declaring variables

source.name: Declaring, Initializing, and Assigning Variables
source.instructions: Construct a program that initializes the variable my_var to 5 and prints it out. Then, re-assigns my_var to 10 and prints it out. The output of the code you are constructing looks like: ```c++ 5 10 ``` **You will not need to use all of the blocks.**
source.guidance:
You will need to declare and assign the appropriate data type and variable to `5` first.

You cannot assign a string (`"10"`) to an `int`.

You cannot re-declare a variable when you reassign (`int my_var = 10;`).

tags.name: Content
tags.value: Declaring Variables, Assigning Variables & Overwriting Variables

source.learningObjectives: SWBAT demonstrate their understanding of declaring, assigning, and overwriting variables

source.name: Variable Names
source.instructions: Which of the following is a correct variable name?
source.guidance:
Here are the basic rules for variable names: 
1. Start with a letter or underscore
2. Remainder of variable name is letters, numbers, or underscores
3. Cannot use a C++ keyword
4. Variables are case sensitive
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain the rules of naming a variable

source.name: Data Types
source.instructions: What are the four basic data types used in C++?
source.guidance:
The four basic data types that you have learned so far are:
- int - integers (no decimal)
- double - numbers with a decimal
- bool - true or false (boolean)
- string - collections of letters, numbers, and symbols
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT name the four basic data types: integers (ints), floats, boolean, and strings

Use **two** `cout` statements to write the following string:
`Okay, it is time to learn about operators.`

source.name: Modulo Calculations
source.instructions: Assuming all numbers below are of type `int`, which of the following is **NOT** correct?
source.guidance: Because modulo is a type of division, you cannot modulo divide by 0. Similar to `/ 0`, `% 0` produces an error.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain the function of the modulo operator

source.name: Adding an Int to a Double
source.instructions: What is **printed** with `cout` when you add an int of `3` and a double of `7.0100` together?
source.guidance: Since `cout` excludes all zeros after a decimal point *unless* they are enclosed by non-zero digits, the last two zeros will not be printed and the result will show `10.01`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain the function of the addition operator

source.name: Incrementing
source.instructions: Select each of the choices below that increments the variable `a` by the value of `1`.
source.guidance: Choices 1, 3, and 4 all increment the variable `a` by the value of `1`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recall how to increment a variable

source.name: Evaluating Boolean Expressions
source.instructions:
Using your knowledge of boolean operators, choose the answer that correctly evaluates the expression below:

`( 5 != 4 ) && ( 3 > 0 ) && ( ! 2 == 3 ) || #unknown condition#`

answers.answer: The expression evaluates to `false` - C++ short circuits because you have a `false` condition with an `&&` operator.
The expression evaluates to `true` - C++ short circuits because you have a `true` condition with an `||` operator.
There is not enough information - we would need to know the `#unknown condition#`.

source.guidance: Because each of the first three conditions evaluates as true, the `&&` operator will cause their combination to evaluate as `true` too. When you reach the `||` operator, you then have `true || #unknown condition#`. C++ short circuits and evaluates the entire line as `true` without ever evaluating the `#unknown condition#`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain the process of type casting

source.name: Evaluating Arithmetic & Boolean Operators
source.instructions:
Determine if the code below returns `true` or `false`.

`(7 >= 7) && (true || 99 < 1) || ! (3 > 5 && 7 < 10) && 2 != 4`
source.guidance:
First, start by evaluating the expressions in the parentheses.

`(7 >= 7)` returns true.
`(true || 99 < 1)` returns true.
`! (3 > 5 && 7 < 10)` returns true.
`2 != 4` returns true.

So the boolean expression is now `true && true || true && true`, which returns `true`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT outline the order of operations

source.name: String Concatenation
source.instructions:
Construct a program that will print:
`I understand string concatenation!`
source.guidance: In C++, strings must use double quotes (") - not single quotes ('). Also, spaces are very important when printing strings.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT organize a program using string concatenation

source.name: Decrementing
source.instructions: Complete the code below by selecting the correct choices according to the comments provided.
source.text:
`int a = 42;`
`int b = 2;`
`//decrement a by 1`
<<<a--;>>>
`//decrement a by b`
<<<a-=b;>>>
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recall how to decrement a variable

source.name: cout vs. printf()
source.instructions: Which of the following programs will print `2.000000` to the console?
source.guidance:
Only choice #4 is correct.
* Choices #1 & #2 use the `cout` command which will not print the decimal point nor any trailing zeros.
* Choice #3 uses the `%d` specifier which indicates an integer, not a double, so an error will be returned.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT differentiate between the printf() and cout functions

source.name: Division
source.instructions: Which of the following statements about division in C++ is **FALSE**?

answers.answer: You can use the division operator with `int`s.
You can use the division operator with `double`s.
Division with `int`s and division with `double`s always yield the same results.
Dividing by `0.0` returns `inf` as an answer.

source.guidance: `int`s and `double`s behave differently with the division operator. Using `double`s will result in a decimal whereas `int`s will result in a whole number with the decimal removed. This means that `10/3` is either a `double` of `3.3333...` or an `int` of `3` based on the declared data type.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define the function of the division operator

source.name: Data Conversion
source.instructions:
Construct a program using the code snippets below to produce the following output:
```c++
false
```
==**Note**== that you only have **ONE ATTEMPT** at this problem.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT organize a program using type casting

source.name: Modulo
source.instructions: What does modulo (`%`) do?

answers.answer: Determines if a number is even or odd
Determines the percentage of two numbers
Returns the remainder after division is performed

source.guidance: Modulo is the remainder after division is performed. So division is a part of modulo, but modulo is not division. Modulo can be used to determine if a number is even or odd, but modulo can do more than that. Finally, the `%` is used with modulo, but modulo does not deal with percentages.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define the function of the modulo operator

source.name: Multiplication
source.instructions: Select each of the choices below where the product (or multiplication) of `a` and `b` is printed.
source.guidance: `x` is not equivalent to the multiplication operator in C++ . The operator `**` is not valid in C++ . Only choices #2 and #4 will result in the product of `a` and `b` being printed to the console.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define the function of the multiplication operator

source.name: Order of Operations
source.instructions: At what priority level does C++ perform modulo (`%`) operations?
source.guidance: Modulo is a type of division, so it is performed along with the `/` and `*` operators in order from left to right.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recall the priority levels of PEMDAS

source.name: PEMDAS Calculations
source.guidance:
The calculations are performed as follow:
1. Parentheses: (125 % 100) = 25
   * -10 + sqrt(25) * 5 / 25
2. Exponents: sqrt(25) = 5
   * -10 + 5 * 5 / 25
3. Multiplication & Division: 5 * 5 / 25 = 1
   * -10 + 1
4. Addition & Subtraction: -10 + 1 = -9
   * -9
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain the rules of PEMDAS with arithmetic operators

source.name: Equality
source.instructions: Enter the appropriate **operator symbol** for each definition.
source.text:
This operator checks if two values are **equal**:
<<<==>>>
This operator **assigns** a value to a variable:
<<<=>>>
This operator checks if two values are **not equal**:
<<<!=>>>
source.guidance:
* The `=` operator assigns a value to a variable
* The `==` operator checks equality between two values
* The `!=` operator checks inequality between two values
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define the function of the equality operator

source.name: Less Than or Equal To True
source.instructions: Select **all** of the conditions below that cause the expression `a <= b` to equate to `true`?

answers.answer: If `a` is both less than and equal to `b`

source.guidance:
There are two conditions that would cause `a <= b` to be `true`. One is if `a` is less than `b` and the other is if `a` is equal to `b`. As long as one of those conditions is true, then `a <= b` will be `true`. 

**Note** that `a` cannot be both less than and equal to `b` at the same time.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain the function of the less than operator

source.name: Greater Than or Equal To True
source.instructions: Select **all** of the expressions below that are true.
source.guidance:
The `>=` operator only returns `true` if the first number is greater than or equal to the second number. So the following statements would evaluate to true:
`19 >= 19` and `19 >= 9`
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain the function of the greater than operator

source.name: Evaluating && Expressions
source.instructions: Fill in the blanks for the following two statements.
source.text:
For an overall `&&` expression to be true, all of its boolean expressions must be <<<true>>>.

For an overall `&&` expression to be false, one or more of its boolean expressions need to be <<<false>>>.
source.guidance:
All of the boolean expressions must be true for the overall `&&` expression to evaluate to `true`.

One or more boolean expressions need to be false for the overall `&&` expression to evaluate to `false`.

For an overall `||` expression to be true, at least one of its boolean expressions needs to be <<<true>>>.
source.guidance:
All of the boolean expressions must be false for the overall `||` expression to evaluate to `false`.

One or more boolean expressions need to be true for the overall `||` expression to evaluate to `true`.

source.name: Evaluating ! Expressions
source.instructions: Evaluate the two expressions below using either **lowercase** `true` or `false`.
source.guidance: Both expressions evaluate to `true`. In the second case, `(5 == 4)` first evaluates to `false` and then `(! (false))` evaluates to `true`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain the function of the not operator

source.name: Short Circuiting
source.instructions: Use the dropdown menus to complete the text below.
source.text:
## Or Operator
When using the `||` operator, C++ checks to see if the first boolean expression is <<<true>>>. If it is <<<true>>>, C++ returns <<<true>>> and ignores the remaining boolean expression(s).

## And Operator
When using the `&&` operator, C++ checks to see if the first boolean expression is <<<false>>>. If it is <<<false>>>, C++ returns <<<false>>> and ignores the remaining boolean expression(s).
source.guidance:
If the first boolean expression for the `||` operator is true, then the entire thing is `true`. The remaining boolean expression(s) is ignored.

If the first boolean expression for the `&&` operator is false, then the entire thing is `false`. The remaining boolean expression(s) is ignored.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define the process of type casting

When using the `||` operator, C++ checks to see if the first boolean expression is

and ignores the remaining boolean expression(s).

## And Operator
When using the `&&` operator, C++ checks to see if the first boolean expression is
and ignores the remaining boolean expression(s).

source.name: Identifying Arithmetic Operators
source.text:
<<<*>>> is the operator for multiplication.
<<<%>>> is the operator for modulo.
<<</>>> is the operator for division.
The <<</>>> operator might return a result different from a calculator's if both numbers are `int`s.
source.guidance:
`*` is the operator for multiplication.
`%` is the operator for modulo.
`/` is the operator for division.
The `/` operator might return a result different from a calculator's if both numbers are `int`s.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define the functions of all arithmetic operators

source.name: String Operator
source.instructions: Which of the following **operators** can be used with strings?
source.guidance: Only the `+` operator can be used with strings. It serves as the concatenation operator by merging two strings together.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recall the process of string concatenation

source.name: List the Order of Operations
source.instructions:
Drag the blocks into the correct order of operations. ==**Note**== that you only have **ONE ATTEMPT** at this problem.

**Hint:** You will not need all of the blocks but make sure that **each** operator is mentioned **once**!
source.initial:
Parentheses
Exponents
Multiplication, Division, and Modulo
Addition and Subtraction
Parentheses and Exponents  #distractor
Multiplication and Division  #distractor
Modulo  #distractor
source.guidance: Order of operations starts with any expression(s) in parentheses. Next, the exponent(s) is calculated. Then multiplication, division, and modulo are calculated from left to right. Finally, addition and subtraction are calculated from left to right.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT list the priority levels for PEMDAS

source.name: Evaluating Mixed Operations
source.instructions:
What is the results of the following expression?

```c++
! (5 != 3) && (5 % 3 >= 2)
```
source.guidance: The first set of parentheses, `(5 != 3)`, evaluates to `true`. The second set of parentheses, `(5 % 3 >= 2)`, also evaluates to `true`. `! true && true` then becomes `false && true` which ultimately evaluates to `false`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT use the order of operations to evaluate expressions

source.name: Compilation Error
source.instructions: When you have fixed the compilation error, click the button below to check your work.
source.guidance:
The compilation bug is located on the following line:
```c++
string b = 9;
```

The bug is that `b` is declared as a `string` but is being assigned to `9` which is an `int`. To correct this, you would replace `string` with `int` which results in:
```c++
int b = 9;
```
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT demonstrate their understanding of data type compatibility

source.name: If Statement Syntax
source.instructions:
Rearrange the code blocks below to create an `if` statement that prints a string if the boolean expression is `true` and then prints **another** string that's **not** associated with the `if` statement.

**Hint:** Not all of the code blocks will be used and **remember** to indent any command(s) that is associated with the `if` statement by dragging it slightly to the *right*.
source.guidance:
Remember that the **three** main components of an `if` statement are:
1. The keyword `if`.
2. A boolean expression inside `()`.
3. An indented command(s) inside `{}` that runs if the boolean expression is `true`.

**Note** that commands not associated with an `if` statement should go outside of the `{}` and should not be indented.

source.name: Variable Test Coverage
source.instructions: Which of the following code segments does **NOT** test for all possible variable values?

source.name: Compound If vs. Nested If
source.instructions: Why might you want to use a **compound conditional** over a **nested** `if` statement?

answers.answer: If a conditional has to be false.
If there is no boolean expression to evaluate.
If you want an `if` statement *inside* another `if` statement.
If you want your code to be more concise and easier to read.

source.guidance: A **compound conditional** and a **nested** `if` statement both allow you to test two or more things to be true. However, compound conditionals tend to have fewer lines of code and are generally easier to read.

source.name: If Statement
source.instructions: Which of the following is **false** regarding `if` statements?

answers.answer: Allows a program to make decisions about what to do.
Allows a specific command(s) to run if the boolean expression is true.
Allows a specific command(s) to run if the boolean expression is false.
Includes the keyword `if`, a boolean expression inside `()`, and a command(s) to run within `{}`.

source.guidance: Choice #3 is false. The program will skip *all* commands within `{}` if the boolean expression evaluates to `false`.

source.name: Even or Odd?
source.instructions: Complete the `if` statement below so that it will determine if the variable `num` is even or odd.

source.name: If Else Syntax
source.instructions: Select **all** of the following that are true regarding an `if-else` statement.

answers.answer: Indentation affects how the code runs.
You need to use curly braces `{}` after both the `if` and the `else` keywords to group code that is conditionally executed.
The `else` condition does not have a boolean expression within parentheses `()` following it.
The `else` condition has empty parentheses `()` following it.

source.guidance:
C++ uses curly braces `{}` to group code commands. While indention is helpful, it does not affect how the program runs. Instead, you need to use curly braces to tell C++ what code to run in both the true condition (after the `if`) and the false condition (after the `else`).

Additionally, because `else` is associated with the `false` condition, it does not need its own boolean expression. Nor does it need parentheses.

source.name: If Else Even or Odd
source.instructions:
Dragging and dropping the code blocks below, construct a program that determines whether the variable `num` is even or odd. **Remember** to **indent** where appropriate or you will not receive any credit for your work.

==**Note**== that you only have **ONE ATTEMPT** at this problem.

source.name: Debugging If Else

answers.answer: Parentheses `()` are missing around the boolean expression after the `if` keyword.
A closing curly brace `}` is missing before the `else` keyword.
Parentheses `()` are missing after the `else` keyword.
An open curly brace `{` is missing after the `else` keyword.

source.name: Nested If Else
source.guidance: Although the `if (windy)` condition is present in the code, it is nested within the `if (rainy)` condition. That means the `if (windy)` condition can't be executed unless the `if (rainy)` condition is true. Since `if (rainy)` is false, the system skips down to the *outer* `else` statement. Also, since the weather is **not** cold, the second nested *inner* `else` statement is executed and thus `"Enjoy your day!"` is provided to you by the device.

source.name: Switch Case Syntax
source.instructions: Which of the following code snippets has the correct `switch case` syntax?
source.guidance:
The following rules need to be met:

`switch (num) { `
The `switch` keyword is followed by the variable in parentheses `()`. The `case` statements are surrounded by a set of curly braces `{}`.

`case "one": number = 1; break;`
Each `case` keyword is followed by a value and a colon `:`. A `break;` goes after the command to run if the variable == the case value and before the next case.

`default: number = -1;`
It is best practice to have the final case be `default`. Since it is the final case, it does not need a `break;` statement.

source.name: Switch Case Usage
source.instructions: Which of the following would a `switch case` statement be **best** used for?

answers.answer: Providing feedback to customers over the phone based on the number they press on their keypad.
Generating ranges of ages of people who work within a company.
Using a car's mileage to determine what services it needs.

source.guidance:
Choices #2 and #3 both require ranges of values for a particular variable to be tested. Thus, an `else if` statement is better for those situations.

A `switch case` statement would work well in the phone example (choice #1) since the customers can only press 10 different buttons with values that do not change.

source.name: Switch Case Key Words
source.instructions: Select the correct key words to make the code below a valid `switch case` statement.

source.name: Switch Case with Pennies
source.instructions: You are programming a children's game where the most "money" they can hold is 4 pennies. Select **all** of the code snippets below that are **valid** for printing out a full list of store items the player can afford to buy based on the number of `pennies` they have.
source.guidance:
Choices #1 & #3 will correctly list all of the items that the player is eligible to buy. They produce the exact same results.

Choice #2 will tell the player what they can get with the *exact* number of pennies in addition to the items that they cannot buy. This happens because there is only 1 `break` statement and it occurs in `case 4`. First the system will match the variable's value to the case's value. It will run that case and continue to run until it sees a `break` or it reaches the end of the `switch case`.

Choice #4 will only tell the player the *one* item they can get with the *exact* number of pennies that they have.
